name: Dawn Simulation Therapy
summary: A light-based intervention that gradually increases light intensity in the morning to simulate a natural sunrise, aiming to improve circadian rhythm alignment and mood.
description:
Dawn simulation therapy uses a timed light device that gradually brightens over 30–90 minutes before a person wakes, mimicking the gradual light changes of a sunrise. This approach aims to gently shift the body's circadian rhythm, enhance morning alertness, and improve mood.

Unlike bright light therapy, which uses high-intensity light shortly after waking, dawn simulation operates at lower lux levels (typically 100–300 lux at eye level) but over a longer ramp-up period. This gradual light increase can be less disruptive for light-sensitive individuals and may improve adherence.

It is most often applied in treating seasonal affective disorder (SAD), circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorders, and certain cases of non-seasonal depression.

contraindications: Bipolar disorder without mood stabilizer (risk of mania)
Severe ocular conditions sensitive to light
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe; minimal side effects compared to bright light therapy.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate for SAD; emerging for circadian rhythm disorders.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Randomized controlled trials show benefit for SAD; mixed evidence for other indications.

sections.text: Dawn simulation gradually increases light exposure before waking, stimulating retinal photoreceptors and influencing the suprachiasmatic nucleus to advance circadian phase and improve mood-regulating neurotransmitter activity.

sections.preparation: Device setup near bed; set wake time and brightness ramp duration.
procedure: Light begins to increase 30–90 minutes before scheduled wake time.
Light intensity peaks at wake time (100–300 lux at eye level).
User wakes to brightened environment simulating sunrise.
sections.frequency: Daily use, especially during darker months or before early shifts.
sections.duration: Ongoing as needed; effects may diminish with discontinuation.
sections.total_treatment_time: Passive during last 30–90 minutes of sleep.

long_term: Sustained mood improvement in winter months

absolute: Active manic episode in bipolar disorder
Severe ocular disease with light sensitivity
special_considerations: Monitor mood in bipolar patients; adjust light intensity for comfort.

practitioner: Not typically required; may be prescribed by clinician

studies: Avery DH, et al. Dawn simulation and bright light in the treatment of SAD: a controlled study. Biol Psychiatry. 2001;50(3):205–216.
Terman M, et al. Light therapy for SAD: A review of efficacy. Am J Psychiatry. 1998;155(5):665–672.
sections.limitations: Effect size smaller than bright light therapy in some trials; requires consistent use.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Device cost only; ongoing electricity minimal
sections.insurance_coverage: Rare; some flexible spending accounts may reimburse
sections.cost_effectiveness: High for SAD prevention and treatment

sections.adolescents: May assist with school start time adaptation; parental guidance recommended.
sections.elderly: Safe and potentially beneficial for sleep maintenance.
sections.comorbidities: Can be adapted for medical conditions with clinician input.

items: More acceptable to patients sensitive to bright light.
May improve adherence due to passive nature.
Best results seen with consistent daily use.
